pros: Lovely place, great colleagues, stimulating environment
cons: Too many changes introduced too quickly

review_title: Lovely Team , but the company don't care about staff
job_title: English Language Teacher in London, England
pros: Lovely teaching team - friendly, helpful, supportive. Beautiful buildings, well-equipped classrooms.
cons: The vast majority of our teaching team are on 0-hours contracts, and received a 2% pay rise this year (vs 3% for the rest of the university) - making life very difficult during a cost-of-living crisis. Our manager has been asking for more permanent contracts for our teaching team for a while, to no avail. The university seems to have a lot of money to spend when it comes to renovating a building which is already beautiful - there is always renovation work going on, often during teaching hours. It seems they focus on this above all, sometimes to the detriment of teaching (disruptive noise).

pros: It seems to be a very good environment to work/to teach. The quality of the courses is very good
cons: As Visiting Lecturer it is difficult to predict the amount of work for the following Term. It is not a secure position.

pros: Fantastic manager and team - great opportunities to do some fanatastic work with Power BI for statutory returns.
cons: Salary not quiet in line with the sector

pros: Work life balance is really good
cons: Pay. Progression. Development. Type of work is quite boring

pros: Good location and great work culture
cons: No big issues to be mentioned

job_title: International Student Adviser in London, England
pros: Working at Regent's was a good opportunity for a first-time employee. Good co-workers that helped make the workday go by. Great location to work, inside Regent's park, close to Baker Street and other central areas of London.
cons: Upper management / Directorate put employees through multiple restructures, I experienced 1 restructure each year I was employed.

pros: Fantastic people, a visionary strategy and room to grow. Regent's is fast-paced and evolving, which may not be for everyone – but for those who want to create, invent and put their stamp on something, it's the place to be. You'll work with employees who share common goals and are striving for the same outcomes.
cons: Other people may see my pros as cons: Regent's may not be for everyone. But people who thrive on fast problem solving and intense creativity will love Regent's.

review_title: Excellent place to work- great growth
pros: The new leadership, game changing UK Education, great location
cons: Speed of change which is also causing turnaround but results speak for themselves

review_title: Not a bad place to work but getting worryingly corporate
job_title: Coordinator, Library Systems in London, England
pros: Nice location, good benefits, good job
cons: The place is getting more and more money focussed and corporate as the days go by and the front line of the university is getting stretched while the numbers people sit happy

review_title: Decent enough but job security a worry
pros: Lecturing staff is generally nice
cons: The pension levels are worryingly low. So renumeration is a problem.

review_title: I am responsible for Marketing of the Brand
job_title: Global Marketing Manager in London, England
pros: The current Senior Management Team is good.
cons: Financial instability as it has been through a tough period.

review_title: What an unethical and terrible place to work! Avoid and run away!
pros: The location is convenient and the park is awesome.
cons:
- Job insecurity - you'll never be sure if you'll keep your job or if the Uni will survive. 
- The University was sold to a French group to avoid bankruptcy. It's the 4th restructure in a couple of years. 
- More than 100 staff made redundant during Christmas 2020. 
- Terrible atmosphere.
- There is no free thinking. You'll be gone if you dare to think different. 
- Hiring friends and friend's companies is a standard procedure. 
- Senior management doesn't care for you, just for the money.
- Abusive managers that perform psychological abuse, bullying and backstabbing
- Lots of illegal stuff happening behind closed doors. 
- Working here was a nightmare.

review_title: Offer positions that do not exist.
job_title: IT Team Leader in London, England
pros: Seemingly friendly people but completely incompetent.
cons:
The university contacted me 2 months after an interview to offer the position. They also stated that they were going into 'partnership' with venture capitalist Galileo Global Education, but they were not, they were being brought outright.
I expressed huge concern that new owners could restructure and that anyone on probation was most likely to be made redundant. I was reassured that the role was 'business critical' and that the partnership was 'a positive step'. So, I signed the contract and handed my notice in to my current employer. 
4 weeks before I was due to start the university contacted me to say that the new owners had restructured and the position was no longer available - exactly as I had warned. 
They had made me unemployed in the middle of a pandemic, I was offered 1 months pay as compensation.

pros: Lovely campus and location in parkland.
cons: Really been going downhill for the last 5 years. Professionally it's a no-go. Poor managment, staff cliquey and overworked.

pros:
It is a solid community within Regent's. 
Beautiful location in Regent's Park. 
Opportunities for professional development.
cons: Recently bought by Galileo Group and the culture feels like it is changing to be more, "keep your head down and work."

cons:
salary below average
unappreciated staff
workload
lots of changes

pros: No there is nothing to say at all
cons: They are very good and very friendly

review_title: Great location, great colleagues that's about it
pros: Lovely faculty and academics to work with and for. The campus location is wonderful especially in the Spring and Summer.
cons: During 4 years of employment, there were 3 restructures. Too much change too close in occurrence was hard to drive forward the new changes to make a dent in productivity expected by upper management/Directorate.

pros: beautiful campus, a few great colleagues, diverse and interesting student body
cons: low salaries, incompetent management, unacceptably high working hours

job_title: Professional Staff Member in London, England
pros:
Regent’s has an amazing campus and some great staff - though most of the good staff are leaving as fast as they can, because of the way they’ve been treated, or they don’t believe in the University’s leadership or future direction as a for profit university, or all of the above. 

There is an interesting student body and many significant challenges to tackle. It is difficult to know what will remain of the current University after its new, for profit owners, Galileo Global Education, have run it through their processes, but there is potential.
cons:
Where to start? The University’s leadership is woeful and its new owners, Galileo Global Education, are focused exclusively on making money. Making money is not a bad thing, but when it involves treating your staff unethically and inhumanely in order to do so, well, you can be the judge of if that’s the kind of company you would like to work for. 

The organisation’s complete restructure has involved chucking nearly 100 staff to the kerb, just two weeks before Christmas, and in the middle of a pandemic - through both VR “opportunities” and a disingenuous interview process for “new” roles leading to forced redundancies. Perhaps worst of all, the restructure has left behind a workforce of both academic and professional staff who do not understand the logic of the restructure or how it will be possible to complete essential business processes in the future. 

Perhaps most concerning is that some of the University’s leadership are so ignorant about the regulatory obligations that apply to the University, that it is only a matter of time before the Office for Students, Quality Assurance Agency and Home Office begin to uncover serious issues and concerning practices.

Unfortunately the University’s salaries are also very low, even by sector standards. They attempt to address this by providing staff with a £3 per day credit in the refectory, but it does not substitute proper compensation.

Finally, as a small, for profit university, Regent’s is struggling to find its way. As an employee you can be assured of little job security, little opportunity to advance your career internally, and little hope of inspiring leadership to plot a way forward. Regent’s is going to be a pretty grim place to work for at least the next 12 to 18 months, and even after that time, unless there is recognition of the issues and significant movement to make improvements.

pros: Good working environment and nice staff
cons: Long hours and tight deadlines

pros: working in a beautiful park and stipend for lunch
cons: low salary and no room for growing

pros: Salary is not too bad
cons: No Union, no flexible working hours, restructuring all the time...

review_title: Not a good place to work Avoid!
pros: Not many - a few nice colleagues. Good location
cons: Highly disorganised- very poor leadership. One of their values is caring - what a joke! No care or consideration really given to staff. Ignore the positive reviews - they’ve been written deliberately to boost the score

pros: Who wouldn't want to work in the centre of Regent's Park or in Marylebone High Street with a lovely bunch of people?  Regent's has a lovely friendly feel and the staff get together for lots of social and work events which include the Grand Autumn Party with students, the annual staff party at Christmas, the annual staff conference and the regular all staff town hall meetings.
cons: It is a small private university so whilst staff do get promoted it has limitations for non academic staff who want fast career progression but that is purely a size issue and the do nurture and develop staff.

job_title: Senior Study Abroad Advisor in London, England
pros:
This was the best interview I've ever had. All the correspondence on the lead up to the interview was clear. The interview day was well prepared. There was a task to complete, a panel interview and also a short tour of the University afterwards. When I was offered the job all the onboarding information was very well presented and again clear, the Recruitment team here are very efficient, quick and personable, it was a pleasure communicatiing with them.
My first day here was well set up, I was introduced around the campus and made to feel really welcome, I even got a free lunch on my first day.
cons: I have only just started here so too early for any cons!

pros: Being part of a close team is a definite pro of working here. The university being so small, it is great to be able to know many different colleagues across the university.
cons: When people leave, it's almost always someone that I know. Those that want faster career progression do tend to depart sooner rather than later.

pros: I've been here 5 years and because it is an independent University, I like the freedom and swiftness in which actions can be made and decisions taken. Also, I can see that my input is taken on board directly and makes a real difference. Sometimes, small is beautiful!
cons: Set in historic buildings with modern facilities in the middle of a beautiful park in Central London. What's not to like?

pros: The location is amazing. Beautiful grounds. Generous annual leave. Pay good compared to competition. Can’t think of anything else. Beautiful buildings. Good facilities.
cons: Non-existent marketing, pointless training, endless meetings... sliding student numbers, gallows-humour morale among staff. Major detachment between staff and management. No clarity on responsibilities. Directors have no idea what’s really going on. Endless list of white elephants. A big, beautiful, sinking ship.

review_title: Dictatorial, non-consultative management divorced from the realities on the ground.
pros: They pay you on time.  Great colleagues.
cons: Layer upon layer of management with little understanding of day-to-day academic work.

pros: The location is brilliant in the middle of Regent's Park, staff are encouraged to have a work/life balance and the people are great
cons: I can't think of any Cons!

pros:
Small, friendly campus
Great annual leave allowance with closure at Christmas! 
Lovely team
cons: Due to Regent's being a small University there isn't much room for promotion, which is a shame.

pros: Pretty relaxed work environment and nice campus overall.
cons: Disorganisation and poor communication reign supreme. These often result into a series of time consuming misunderstandings and ill performed tasks. There is absolutely no recognition or reward for talent, extra hour, and effort. If anything you feel belittle every single day.
